awd_titl_txt: Bilateral BBSRC-NSF/BIO: CIBR: Structural modeling of interactome to assess phenotypic effects of genetic variation.
awd_abstract_narration:
Structural characterization of protein interactions is essential for interpretation of genetic variation. A vast amount of information on single amino acid variants will be available from sequencing. The project focuses on application of computational approaches to the development of a public resource incorporating structural modeling with genetic amino acid variants and assessment of their functional impact. The resource will facilitate better understanding of principles of protein interaction and structure/function relationships. The long-term goal of this research is to gain insights into fundamental principles of molecular processes in living systems, leading to structure-based description of the cell. The collaborative project combines highly complementary areas of expertise of the US team, on high-throughput modeling of protein-protein interactions, and the UK team, on protein structure prediction and effects of genetic variation. The teams will coordinate research and training activities, based on the project, with graduate and undergraduate programs locally, nationally and internationally. Minority students and women will be involved in different parts of the research, including those within established minority-oriented programs. The project will enhance infrastructure for research and education. The US and UK teams have an extensive and well proven record of developing and disseminating public resources, used by many researchers worldwide. The project participants will be actively presenting their results at various multidisciplinary conferences and workshops. 

The project will continue development of an integrated approach to high-throughput modeling of proteins and their complexes. The objectives of the project are: (1) to develop advanced high-throughput approaches to modeling of protein interactome; (2) to provide assessment of phenotypic effects of genetic variation; and (3) to develop and implement genome-wide resource for structural characterization of interactome and phenotypic effects of genetic variation. The structure modeling approaches will be based on new search, scoring and refinement strategies, and will integrate the tertiary and quaternary structure prediction. The prediction of the mutation effect will evaluate the change in protein interactions. The genome-wide GWYRE resource will incorporate structurally refined protein complexes for model organisms annotated by the phenotypic effects of the single amino acid variants. The project outcome will have a significant impact on the research field by integrating template-based tertiary and quaternary structure prediction, and development of a comprehensive public resource for structural characterization of interactomes and assessment of phenotypic effects of genetic variation. The results of the project will be available at http://www.gwyre.org and also at http://vakser.compbio.ku.edu and http://www.sbg.bio.ic.ac.uk.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. The focus of the project was on development and implementation of approaches and resources for modeling of proteins and protein interactions and structure-based assessment of missense variants. The project was productive, resulting in new predictive approaches to interpretation of genetic variation and implementation of the GWYRE public resource. The results of the US and UK teams collaboration were reported at major international conferences and journal papers. 

Developments in protein docking aim at improvement of applicability, accuracy, and utility of modeling macromolecular complexes. The challenges include the need for proper accounting of conformational flexibility, new deep learning-based methodologies, affinity prediction, and development of fully automated docking servers. Comparative analysis of knowledge-based docking was performed utilizing different template libraries (full/interface vs. sequence homology). Significant improvement was observed when the same template was selected by both methods. By adding templates identified by sophisticated sequence/evolutionary based techniques, the near-native models were generated for most protein-protein complexes.

Docking constraints are essential for the prediction of protein binding modes. Publicly available results of biological research can be the source of such constraints. Our text-mining tool, which extracts binding site residues from published abstracts, was applied to protein-protein docking. An extension of the tool further improved the performance by utilizing natural language processing to analyze the context of the residue occurrence.

A large-scale analysis of conformational changes upon binding provided the basis for the development of algorithms for sidechain repacking in protein docking. To facilitate the use of these results by the community, a Web-based interface for the libraries of sidechain rotamers and rotamer-rotamer transition probabilities was implemented. Conformational properties of protein interfaces were studied using rotamer libraries in comparative analysis of protein-protein and protein-ligand interfaces. The results determined the scope of the conformational changes and provided guidelines for the refinement. A flexible interface refinement protocol was developed and benchmarked.

Modeling of the cell-sized macromolecular systems increasingly tops the agenda in computational biology field, due to the progress in structural modeling of individual molecules based on the deep learning methodologies. We developed an approach that bridges protein docking and molecular simulations, based on the efficient sampling of the pre-computed protein-protein docking positions. The atomic resolution approach is capable of reaching extra-long simulation trajectory lengths for cell-sized systems, offering key advantages in adequate determination of the phenotypic effects of genetic mutations.

The pool of structural data for modeling of proteins and protein-protein complexes is constantly increasing due to the rapid growth of protein structures/interactions databases. The GWYRE project capitalized on these developments by applying new methodologies to modeling of protein-protein interactions and genetic variation. The predictions were incorporated in a public resource for structural characterization of interactome and location of the genetic variants.

Broader impacts. The results of the project were used by the research community to study macromolecular interactions and to characterize phenotypic effects of genetic mutations. The results were presented to high-school students in regional school districts. Project materials were included in the graduate course for Computational Biology students. The project involved training and professional development of graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs. Minority students and women were involved in different parts of the project. The students in the project were training to become experts in biomolecular modeling, including applications to biologically important problems, structure refinement, and modeling of interactomes. They gained name recognition through publications and participation in top international conferences. This provided them with a solid foundation for a successful professional career in Computational Biology and Bioinformatics. The results were reported at Computational Biology seminar series, which attracts broad audience from various departments and neighboring institutions. The project outcomes were discussed at the international community-wide CAPRI (Critical Assessment of Predicted Interactions) initiative.

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2023
Modified by: Ilya A Vakser
